. Are you using Let's Encrypt certificate? Use
ssl_certificate /etc/letsencrypt/live/your.awesome.domain/fullchain.pem;
    ssl_certificate_key /etc/letsencrypt/live/your.awesome.domain/privkey.pem;
instead of
ssl_certificate /etc/letsencrypt/live/your.awesome.domain/cert.pem;
    ssl_certificate_key /etc/letsencrypt/live/your.awesome.domain/privkey.pem;
Will ensure cert working on any application.
Also configuration below is acting like a Twitter API server, without any other requirement.
```
server {
    listen 443 ssl;
    server_name  your.awesome.domain;
ssl_certificate /etc/letsencrypt/live/your.awesome.domain/fullchain.pem;
ssl_certificate_key /etc/letsencrypt/live/your.awesome.domain/privkey.pem;

location ~ ^/domain.([\w\d]+)/(.*) {
    resolver 8.8.8.8;
    proxy_pass  https://$1.twitter.com/$2$is_args$args;
proxy_cookie_domain twitter.com $server_name;
}

location / {
    root /var/www/your.awesome.domain;
}

}
``

I just dug through the twitter API docs and found some thoughts about rate limiting:
- There does not seem to be a way to check in advance how many tweets can be sent in the next 15 minutes without getting back a rate limit error. GET application/rate_limit_status does not seem to cover POST statuses/update (https://dev.twitter.com/rest/reference/get/application/rate_limit_status)
- There does not seem to be a fixed rate limit for POST statuses/update: https://dev.twitter.com/rest/public/rate-limits
- All I can find is "2400 tweets per day, but sublimits exist" (https://support.twitter.com/articles/355430). This article can be seen as a hint that status updates are limited to 50 tweets per 30 minute sliding window. On the other hand, the rate limiting docs talk about 15 minute sliding windows, so we're down to 25 tweets in a burst (=immediately sending the next tweet when the server replies with "success").
- Taking into account that the user needs some time to write a tweet chain (and therefore did not send a tweet in the last 15 minutes or so), I think it's safe to assume that tweet chains up to 25 tweets could be sent in a burst, while longer tweet chains should wait at least 45 seconds between each tweet request. Simple solution to that: limit tweet chains to 25 tweets. Sounds good enough :)
- Taking the HTTP response headers "X-Rate-Limit-*" into account to throttle the tweeting rate might be a good idea, but my experience with them did not yield any usable result yet (might also be the fault of the library I'm using or me using that library wrong). -> https://dev.twitter.com/rest/public/rate-limiting

vphantom:
Actually my main problem is that the hiding/revealing of the compose buton and the title bar are exactly backwards of what is naturally expected: when we're scrolling towards the top (finger top-down) while catching up chronologically, both are shown, and when we're scrolling into the past (finger down-top, towards older tweets at bottom), they are hidden to give us more room for some reason.
This UI behavior seems to assume that people read the newest tweets first, and catch up with progressively older tweets in reverse order until they see something they remember, like what the Twitter web site itself does (which is crazy - after all these years they still don't save timeline positions and no user seems to care).  That's nuts for someone like me who uses Twitter mostly for news; I make the client remember my timeline position specifically so that I can catch up in chronological order.
So anyway, my work-around is to "over-scroll" by about 1cm, then scroll back up 1cm to make the compose key and title bar disappear, giving me the most screen real estate.  I'd inverse this behavior if I could, but like I said I'm not well-versed here.  Java I could work with, but I know nothing of the massive Android API.
. The latest update of Twidere I received, 3.1.4.2, completely solves this by hiding the tabs and the pesky compose button when we're scrolling to catch up to the present. :smiley:

Just find out the related bug report: https://issuetracker.google.com/issues/64434571
Workaround:

If you need to build with 3.0 but are running into this bug you can disable aapt2 using -Pandroid.enableAapt2=false on the command line when doing your build.

Explanation:

CyanogenMod has this function getPkgName (https://github.com/CyanogenMod/android_frameworks_base/blob/cm-13.0/libs/androidfw/AssetManager.cpp).  It creates a ResXMLTree on the stack and points it at a buffer from an asset without making a copy.  Then it closes the asset before the ResXMLTree is destroyed.
For apps built by aapt, this is benign.  However, aapt2 produces UTF-8 string pools, which cause the ResXMLTree's ResStringPool(mStrings)'s mCache to become non-null in ResStringPool::stringAt (https://github.com/CyanogenMod/android_frameworks_base/blob/cm-13.0/libs/androidfw/ResourceTypes.cpp).  Then ResStringPool::uninit dereferences mHeader (which is now dangling), and a crash ensues.
This crash shows up in different ways.  On one Cyanogen OS device, the launcher crashes when an app built with aapt2 has been installed, but only if the manifest is large (probably due to how deallocation happens for small vs large blobs).  On another device, system_server crashes at boot if an aapt2-built app is installed..
